Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: A sudden route closure forces dozens of flights into tight holding stacks around the airport.
Story: The headset pressed tight against my ears, voices crackling in rapid succession as I scanned the radar. A route closure had just been announced, and the airspace was a tangled mess of holding patterns, each blip representing hundreds of lives depending on my focus. My hands hovered over the console, ready to issue new instructions, when my phone buzzed insistently. It was my stepbrother, and the message was short: “Call me. It’s urgent.” I knew he’d been waiting for news about our dad’s health, and the timing could only mean it was bad. My heart twisted—he needed me, needed the kind of support we’d promised each other since our families merged. But the radio squawked again, another pilot requesting vectors, and I could feel the weight of every expectation pressing down. My family needed my comfort, but the skies demanded my undivided attention. I stared at the blinking lights, torn between the chaos above and the pain waiting on the other end of the line, caught in a moment where I couldn’t be both the sibling he needed and the controller everyone depended on.
